name: TheAtlantic
text: Over the course of the coronavirus crisis, @khushbuoshea’s relatives have sent her homeopathic “cures,” astrological charts predicting the end of the pandemic, and conspiracy theories. She writes about why misinformation spreads in families: https://t.co/mrFTentgZd

name: TheAtlantic
text: iPads wrapped in plastic bags. Zoom goodbyes. The coronavirus made caring for the sickest patients “an entirely new universe,” @sarahzhang reports. https://t.co/SALiOOQBij

name: TheAtlantic
text: Understanding the present moment requires grappling with a history stained by racial inequity. We compiled a list of writing on race and racism spanning @TheAtlantic's 163-year history: https://t.co/UdUDRh9hPc

name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen: Supplements and vitamins claim to “boost your immune system.” @JamesHamblin explains why this is nonsense. https://t.co/JtL3Rnm9g3

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @prashantrao: If you want to understand what went wrong in Hong Kong, @TMclaughlin3's profile of Carrie Lam contains incredible detail, color, and depth, based on dozens of interviews and months of reporting.

And yet, as he notes, she is not the problem: https://t.co/zUroCVNuQD

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YAppelbaum: "When we ignore the dialectical relation between the labels “black” and “white,” we treat a bloodstained product of history as a neutral, objective fact about the world,” writes @KAnthonyAppiah https://t.co/LvYa6JkxLA

name: TheAtlantic
text: The former national security adviser's much-awaited, and controversially timed, tell-all appears to paint a president at his worst. From @mimbsy: https://t.co/m04L0XbE67

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @denisewills: This story is incredible. https://t.co/9HN9SHnxQx

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: Carrie Lam has been a unique failure as Hong Kong's leader. Yet she is merely the symptom of its ills, @TMclaughlin3 writes, in this deeply-reported and thoughtful profile, which delves into both the person, and the system, that has doomed Hong Kong: https://t.co/zUroCVvTZ5

name: TheAtlantic
text: "How do the human beings whom communities hire, train, and supervise," @R_T_Rybak writes, "end up killing people they are supposed to protect and serve?" https://t.co/Nn6sEXIwM9

name: TheAtlantic
text: Carrie Lam has been a unique failure as Hong Kong's leader. Yet she is merely a symptom of the city's ills, @TMclaughlin3 writes: https://t.co/0usfF3MFmB

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @russellberman: In Arizona and Texas, mayors and county leaders are confronting a resurgence of coronavirus cases with their hands tied by Republican governors https://t.co/9rqbgiMIRi

name: TheAtlantic
text: In this week’s “How to Build a Life,” @arthurbrooks explains how embracing negative feelings leads to emotional strength, which in turn leads to a good, meaningful life: https://t.co/BRclvsqOuC

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @julieebeck: in this week’s How to Build a Life, @arthurbrooks argues that negative emotions are a necessary part of a good life—and gives strategies for coexisting with them peacefully
https://t.co/seU8Qnq9Ly

name: TheAtlantic
text: If HBO’s Roy Cohn documentary “Bully. Coward. Victim.” tends to dart around its subject, it’s nonetheless a fascinating addition to the canon for those who seek to understand Trump, writes @sophieGG: https://t.co/mpQOqzR3Mo

name: TheAtlantic
text:
The Supreme Court upheld the DACA program for young, undocumented immigrants, in a ruling against the Trump administration.

In November 2019, Garrett Epps wrote about the dangers of rescinding the program for the nearly 700,000 people who rely on it. https://t.co/Z7db4nP1MH
